We provide a categorical definition of quantum theory, which is independent of any analytical structure. The definition is purely categorical and does not presuppose any knowledge of quantum mechanics. The axioms are designed to be as simple as possible, and we believe that they are the simplest possible. We believe that this work will be of interest to researchers in the foundations of quantum theory, as well as to researchers in quantum information theory and quantum computation.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that cause diseases in a wide range of hosts, including humans. The evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been enigmatic, and a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies. Here, we present the first comparative genomic analysis of two distantly related myxozoan species and a less reduced cnidarian parasite. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. These results provide insights into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to evade the host immune response is one of the most important factors that determine the success of their replication and propagation in the host. In this study, we describe a mechanism by which SARS-CoV-2, the causative agent of COVID-19, is able to block the nuclear import of IFN-stimulated genes, which is a key step in the induction of antiviral immune response. Our results provide a better understanding of the mechanisms used by SARS-CoV-2 to evade the antiviral action of IFN and may help in the development of new antiviral strategies. (Show more)

The proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1, but the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 is not completely understood. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 dimer. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. We show that the variability of maize yields will increase substantially in the future, even if the mean yield increases. This increase in variability will increase the risk of large production losses in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries. Our results also show that the instability of global grain trade and international grain prices will increase, especially for the poorest countries. These results highlight the need for investments in breeding maize varieties that are better able to cope with the heat stress that is already affecting maize production in many parts of the world.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a fundamental question in ecology. We show that DNA metabarcoding can be used to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap at a species level, and that this approach can be used to show that the extent of diet partitioning varies among species, even when they are similar in body size. Our results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may be misleading in understanding the role of large herbivores in ecosystems. Our findings have implications for understanding the role of LMH diversity in ecosystems and the extent to which LMH coexistence is based on niche partitioning. This work also highlights the need for further development of DNA metabarcoding as a tool for understanding the diets of large herbivores. This will be critical for understanding the role of LMH in ecosystems and for the conservation of these species.

We conducted a large survey of small businesses in the United States during the early stages of the COVID-19 crisis. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. However, many businesses are financially fragile, and many more are on the brink of financial collapse. We also find that many businesses are planning to apply for the new federal loans, but they anticipate problems with the application process.

Plastic debris is one of the most visible consequences of human activities in the ocean. However, the magnitude of the problem is still debated. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. Our observations of the size distribution of floating plastic debris point at important size-selective sinks removing millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic on a large scale. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean. View Full-Text

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important questions in astronomy. We present the first ages of presolar silicon carbide grains, which are the first products of stars and are considered to be the oldest material in the solar system.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the number of motorized vessels has increased by a factor of 10. The expansion of the motorized fleet has been driven by the powered-artisanal fleet, which has increased by a factor of 100. The powered-artisanal fleet is the most numerous sector of the global fleet, but it contributes only a quarter of the global engine power. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased by a fifth since 1950, and the effective CPUE of the global fleet has decreased by a third. The effective CPUE of the global fleet has stabilized in recent years, but the global catch has continued to increase. The expansion of the global fleet will continue to challenge the sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to increase the energy available to the mother is a key factor in the success of all species that practice allonursing. We show that the increase in reproductive output is not due to an increase in the number of litters produced but rather an increase in the size of litters. This increase in reproductive power is due to the increase in the amount of energy available to the mother, rather than an increase in the number of litters produced.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes, the cells that produce myelin in the brain. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which is currently in clinical use for the treatment of epilepsy, is able to reduce the load of α-syn aggregates in a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, which is a hallmark of MSA pathology. Our results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate for the treatment of MSA. This would be the first disease-modifying treatment for MSA. (Show more)

The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the body. It is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between the blood and the tissues. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells and is responsible for controlling the contractility of the blood vessels, controlling the clotting of the blood, and controlling inflammation. The endothelium is a complex system that is composed of thousands of specialized cells that are connected to each other in a network. This network is responsible for integrating the multitude of signals that are received from the blood and the tissues. This paper provides a detailed description of the structure of the endothelial network and the nature of the communication between the cells. The findings of this paper will help to understand the structure and function of the endothelium and will help to develop new strategies for the treatment of vascular diseases.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. We describe the design and implementation of a data API that provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 surveillance signals, including cases, deaths, hospitalizations, and many auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity. These are available at a fine geographic resolution (mostly at the county level) and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. We believe that this data infrastructure will be useful to policy makers, epidemiological modelers, and researchers in the ongoing effort to understand and combat the pandemic.

The selectivity filter and the activation gate in potassium channels are functionally and structurally coupled. This allosteric coupling underlies C-type inactivation coupled to activation gating in this ion-channel family. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We show that the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter is the molecular basis for the allosteric coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. This work provides a structural explanation for the functional coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter, and it may have implications for the design of new drugs for potassium channels. The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is thought to play a role in the health of the host. However, the role of the microbiome in disease is not well understood. One of the most important questions is whether the microbiome is a source of natural products that could be used as therapeutics. Here, we show that anaerobic fungi in the gut produce a variety of natural products, including antibiotics, that could be used to treat disease.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, but the role of personality traits in the establishment of social hierarchies is poorly understood. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that predisposes individuals to become subordinate during a social encounter, is associated with reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. We further demonstrate that the low probability to become dominant in high-anxious animals is due to a reduction in mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens and that this is reversed by nicotinamide, a vitamin B3 metabolite that enhances brain energy metabolism. Our findings suggest that mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens is crucial for social hierarchy establishment and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. This study provides a link between brain energy metabolism and social behavior and may lead to the development of new treatments for anxiety-related social disorders. (PsycINFO Database Record

This work is a paradigm shift in the design of mechanical devices. It is a significant step forward in the development of the design of composite materials and structures, which is a key area of research in the field of materials science. The work is also a milestone in the development of the design of mechanical devices, which is a rapidly growing field.

Hemoglobin is the oxygen-carrying protein of erythrocytes. The hemoglobin system is a key regulator of oxygen delivery to tissues and is therefore a key factor in the health and survival of the organism. The hemoglobin system is also a target of evolution, and the hemoglobin system has been subject to evolution in humans and other species. Here we show that the hemoglobin system is subject to developmental regulation in humans, and that this regulation is mediated by a protein that is involved in the regulation of RNA stability. This work provides a mechanism for developmental regulation of the hemoglobin system in humans and may have implications for the evolution of hemoglobin in humans and other species.

Cancer is a disease of the uncontrolled growth of cells, and the development of cancer is associated with a variety of genetic mutations. In this study, we found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling pathway confers resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis that is regulated by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. This resistance is mediated by sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism, and monounsaturated fatty acids produced by stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1 (SCD1). In addition, we found that the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction shows therapeutic promise in preclinical models of cancer. These findings suggest that ferroptosis may be a promising therapeutic target for cancer treatment. (Show more)

Hypertension is the most common risk factor for heart failure, and the treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of cardiovascular disease prevention. However, the use of antihypertensive drugs is associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular events. The present study provides a mechanism for the association of L-type Ca2+ channel blockers with cardiovascular disease.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP was effective in halting the decline of older-forest–associated bird species, but not early-seral–associated species. Our findings suggest that the NWFP has not yet been successful in reversing the decline of older forests, and that the early-seral ecosystem created under the NWFP may be a valuable tool for the conservation of early-seral bird species.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge, and computational approaches are essential tools to this end. In this work, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. The best candidate is synthetically more accessible, exhibits higher solubility and binding affinity to the ribosome, and is up to 56 times more active against resistant pathogens than telithromycin. Notably, the best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. Our study provides a proof of concept for the use of computational approaches in the rational design of new antibiotics. This approach can be extended to other antibiotic classes. This work is expected to contribute to the development of new antibiotics to fight antibiotic resistance. (Show more)

We introduce a new architecture for deep convolutional neural networks that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters. The proposed architecture is based on a simple idea: use dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connect all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We show that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters than popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems. We believe that the proposed architecture will be useful for many applications in computer vision and image processing. We hope that the proposed architecture will be useful to the computer vision community.

The evolution of the African Rift System and the formation of Lake Malawi are among the most significant events in the history of the continent. This study provides a continuous record of the hydroclimate of the region over the last 1.3 My, and shows that the formation of the lake was the result of a dramatic shift in the effective moisture of the region. This shift is associated with a change in the orbital forcing of the climate, which is consistent with the Mid-Pleistocene Transition. The lake level variations are closely linked to the evolution of the cichlid fish species flock, which is one of the most diverse fish communities on Earth. The results presented here provide a unique insight into the evolution of the African Rift System and the formation of Lake Malawi, and the role that climate change played in the diversification of the endemic cichlid fish species flock. The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. However, the biological effects of these devices on sleep and health are not well understood. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and reduces the ability to fall asleep and stay asleep. These results have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety. The results also suggest that the use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime may be contributing to the decline in sleep duration and quality in the United States and around the world. This decline in sleep may be contributing to the rise in obesity, diabetes, cardiovascular disease, and cancer.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a well-known event in the Earth sciences, but its cause is still debated. One of the most widely accepted hypotheses is that one or more bolide impacts triggered the cooling. However, the evidence for such impacts is not conclusive. We show that the osmium isotope composition of the sediments and magnetic grains/microspherules from the YDB sites in the United States are consistent with terrestrial sources, and the spherules from the YDB in Pennsylvania are consistent with an impact origin.

The role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity has been controversial. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice, but not in congenital deficiency. This is due to the ability of CTLA-4–deficient T cells to induce autoimmunity de novo, and to the ability of CTLA-4–deficient Treg cells to suppress autoimmunity.

Beetles are the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of this order remains poorly understood. We used the most comprehensive dataset of beetle genomes to date to resolve the evolutionary history of this group. Our results suggest that the evolution of beetles was driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivores following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding enzymes that enable digestion of plant cell walls. Our study provides insights into the evolution of the most speciose group of animals and the origins of their major ecological and economic importance. (Less)

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of new therapeutics and vaccines against SARS-CoV-2 variants. (Show more)

We report the results of a large-scale experiment that investigates the extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution. We find that, contrary to popular belief, larger populations do not enhance cumulative cultural evolution. We also find that the extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution depends on the conditions under which they are used. Our results have implications for the evolution of technology and the development of human societies.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is the APOE4 allele. APOE is a protein that is produced by astrocytes, a major cell type in the brain. We found that APOE isoform regulates the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis, which is highly dependent on APOE isoform. APOE2 enhances the rate of phagocytosis of synapses by astrocytes, whereas APOE4 decreases it. We also found that the presence of APOE4 increases the accumulation of a complement component in the brain, which may be due to the increased rate of phagocytosis of senescent synapses by astrocytes. These studies suggest that the presence of APOE4 may be due to defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes, which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. This hypothesis may help to explain the increased risk of AD associated with the APOE4 allele.

The inner core is a solid sphere that is 1,220 km in diameter and has a density of 12.0 g/cm3. It is the densest part of the Earth, and its structure and formation mechanism are still poorly understood. The most widely accepted model is that the inner core formed by the solidification of a metal core. However, this model is not consistent with the fact that the inner core is a solid sphere, and it also cannot explain the structure and anisotropy of the inner core. In this study, we propose a new model for the formation of the inner core, which is based on the nucleation of the inner core.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that the brain DA response to methylphenidate (a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine) is reduced in marijuana abusers, which might contribute to their negative emotionality and addictive behaviors. These findings highlight the need to investigate the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain.

Language is the defining feature of modern humans, and the brain’s processing of language is central to our intelligence. However, the brain’s language system is not understood, in part because of the difficulty of studying the brain’s processing of language in humans. Here, we show that a deep learning approach to neuroscience can help. We show that a large number of deep learning models, trained on unrelated tasks, can explain nearly all of the brain’s activity during language processing in humans. These results provide computational evidence for the existence of a language system in the brain, and suggest that it is predictive processing that shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it has been criticized for its instability. We show that this instability is a consequence of the difficulty of the optimization problem that DL algorithms solve. We prove that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks, but there are no algorithms that can train such networks. This result has implications for the design of DL algorithms and for the stability of deep learning models in scientific computing.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including a failure to understand exponential growth. This paper is about one of the most cited studies in psychology, which has been used to support this claim. The study’s authors have been criticized for failing to control for the effects of the participants’ expectations, but they have also been criticized for not realizing that their study was flawed. This paper shows that both criticisms are valid, and that the study’s authors were not aware of the flaws at the time of the study. The paper concludes with a discussion of the implications of this case study for the use of psychological research in the study of human behavior.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for centuries, and the cause of the disease has been debated for even longer. In this study, we sequenced the genome of a new species of leprosy bacterium, which was isolated from a Mexican patient with leprosy. We also compared the genome of this new species with that of the leprosy bacterium that has been the focus of most research. Our results suggest that the two leprosy bacteria have diverged little since they diverged from their common ancestor, and that they are still able to cause similar diseases. This study provides a foundation for further research on the biology of leprosy and may lead to the development of new therapies. (Show more)

The dynamics of entanglement and entropy in quantum many-body systems is a central topic of current research. In this work, we provide a complete description of the dynamics of entanglement in the space–time scaling limit, which is the appropriate limit to study the evolution of the entanglement of formation. Our result is based on the integrability of the model and the quasiparticle picture of the entanglement dynamics. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain and find perfect agreement. Our work provides a powerful tool to study the dynamics of entanglement in a wide class of interacting systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has resulted in millions of deaths worldwide. The only vaccine currently in clinical development is the one developed by Pfizer and BioNTech. This study describes a vaccine candidate that is similar to the Pfizer vaccine in terms of its safety and efficacy. The vaccine candidate is temperature sensitive, which may make it easier to manufacture. The vaccine candidate is also easy to manufacture at large scale, which may make it easier to distribute. The vaccine candidate is also easy to store, which may make it easier to administer. The vaccine candidate is a live attenuated vaccine, which may make it easier to administer. The vaccine candidate is a spike protein vaccine, which may make it easier to administer.

Plague, caused by Yersinia pestis, is one of the most devastating diseases in human history. The Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. We present a mathematical model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. Using Bayesian inference, we found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for pneumonic or rodent transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. Our findings have implications for the history of plague, as well as for the spread of infectious diseases today.

The evolution of brain size has been a major focus of comparative neuroethology. However, the evolution of brain information-processing capacity has been less studied. Here, we show that the evolution of brain size is not the only factor that determines the cognitive capacity of animals. We show that the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is driven by the evolution of the number of neurons, not by the evolution of brain mass. This study has important implications for the study of the evolution of animal cognition.

We have identified a role for TRAP1 in the regulation of mitochondrial metabolism and function. This work provides a basis for further investigation of the role of TRAP1 in the regulation of cancer cell metabolism and invasiveness.

Actin filaments are the main cytoskeletal elements in cells, and they are dynamically assembled and disassembled by a number of proteins. One of these proteins, cofilin, is known to be involved in the regulation of actin filament dynamics. However, the mechanism by which cofilin regulates actin filament dynamics is not fully understood. Here, we show that the action of cofilin can be enhanced by mechanical forces, and that this enhancement is critical for the regulation of actin filament dynamics. Our results provide a mechanistic explanation for the role of cofilin in the regulation of actin filament dynamics, and they have implications for the role of cofilin in cells.

Fructose, a common sweetener found in many foods and beverages, is a popular choice for dieters. However, the effects of fructose on brain and behavior have not been systematically investigated. We show that fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of obesity and for the design of interventions to reduce the consumption of fructose. Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. We also found that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a sex-biased way, with a higher contribution of males from Southeast Asia and Europe. Finally, we found that the genetic structure of the population is influenced by geography, suggesting that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a dynamic way, with a high rate of genetic exchange. These results help to understand the history of Madagascar and the settlement of the Indian Ocean. View Full-Text

We show that people’s emotions can be influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook. This work has implications for the design of social networks, as well as for the study of the influence of social networks on society.

The presence of a single nucleotide modification in messenger RNAs can have a profound impact on protein synthesis. In this work, we show that the presence of a single pseudouridine (Ψ) in messenger RNAs can alter the rate of protein synthesis. We also show that the presence of Ψ in messenger RNAs can increase the rate of near-cognate amino acid incorporation. Our results suggest that the presence of Ψ in messenger RNAs can alter the rate of protein synthesis and suggest that Ψ can be a potential target for the development of new antibiotics. (Show more)

We show that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, stronger social relationships, and a healthier lifestyle. This study highlights the importance of a sense of purpose in the maintenance of health and well-being across the life course.

The evolution of body size in mammals is one of the most studied topics in biology. We show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. This size attractor is consistent with the energetic constraints of the aquatic medium.

The common cold is the most common infectious disease in the world, and rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. Despite the prevalence of rhinovirus, the mechanisms that allow it to replicate preferentially in the nasal cavity are not well understood. Here, we show that the temperature at which rhinovirus replicates is influenced by the innate immune response of infected cells. We also show that the innate immune response of infected cells is less efficient at cool temperature, which may contribute to the preferential replication of rhinovirus at nasal cavity temperature. These findings may help to explain the preference of rhinovirus for the nasal cavity and may lead to the development of new strategies for the prevention and treatment of the common cold. (Show more)

This study demonstrates that the type IV pili of Pseudomonas aeruginosa are used as a sensor for the mechanical activity of the cell surface, and that this sensing mechanism is used to regulate the expression of virulence factors. This is the first demonstration of a bacterial mechanosensory system, and the first demonstration of a bacterial mechanochemical model.

This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation and its impact on surface water quality. We show that the presence of pesticides in surface water is widespread and that the risk of exceeding the legally accepted regulatory threshold levels is high. This study is a call for action to improve the monitoring of pesticides in surface water and to reduce the use of newer-generation insecticides.

This study is the first to document the presence of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer. The findings suggest that deer are not only susceptible to SARS-CoV-2 infection but also act as a reservoir for the virus. This has important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic. Our study highlights the need for a “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. This study also provides a unique opportunity to study the impact of the pandemic on the health of deer populations. Further research is needed to assess the impact of SARS-CoV-2 infection on deer health and to evaluate the potential for deer to act as a source of infection for humans. (Show more)

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, biodiversity, and the livelihoods of people living in the areas where they are built. This paper examines the reasons for the proliferation of large dams in the developing world and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) protein is the primary pathological hallmark of the disease. However, the role of Aβ in the initiation and progression of AD is still unclear. Here, we show that neurons, which are the main cell type in the brain, are also involved in the inflammatory response in AD. Our results suggest that the accumulation of Aβ in the brain may be the primary cause of the neuroinflammation that is observed in AD.

The history of the chicken is one of the most fascinating in the history of agriculture. It is also one of the most enigmatic, as the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation is still missing. We present a detailed analysis of the faunal assemblage from the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, and show that the exploitation of chickens for economic purposes was widespread at that site already in the fourth century B.C.E. This finding challenges the current view that the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens is restricted to the Mediterranean region and provides a new perspective on the history of the chicken. We have developed a method that allows the study of the folding of a large protein at high resolution. We have used this method to study the folding of the maltose binding protein, a protein that has been studied for many years. We have found that the folding of the protein is more complex than previously thought.

In bacteria, the accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates in response to stress is thought to be a mechanism for regulating gene expression. However, the precise role of these molecules in stress adaptation is not well understood. Here, we show that, in response to stress, a previously unidentified RNA pyrophosphohydrolase, RppH, is the predominant enzyme responsible for decapping dinucleoside tetraphosphate-capped transcripts. This enzyme has a unique substrate recognition mechanism, which is critical for its ability to deprotect dinucleoside tetraphosphate-capped RNAs. Our findings suggest that the role of dinucleoside tetraphosphate in stress adaptation is more complex than previously thought and that the precise mechanism by which this molecule functions in bacteria is more complex than previously thought. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with a high mortality rate. Although the immune system is activated in response to the presence of pathogens, it can become dysfunctional, leading to the development of a proinflammatory state that is characterized by lymphopenia, increased apoptosis, and the emergence of myeloid-derived suppressor cells and regulatory T cells. In this study, we show that the administration of citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is able to restore the function of T cells and decrease the expansion of regulatory T cells and myeloid-derived suppressor cells in a mouse model of sepsis. These results suggest that citrulline could be a promising therapeutic strategy for the treatment of sepsis. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. (Show more)

The biomass of all living organisms is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a quantitative view of the biomass composition of the biosphere is still lacking. Here, we assemble a census of the biomass of all kingdoms of life, revealing that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. We also show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all mammals combined, and that the biomass of humans is about two orders of magnitude higher than that of all plants combined. Our results highlight the importance of humans in the global biomass composition and the need for a better understanding of the impact of humans on the biomass of wild species. This information is essential for the conservation and sustainable use of biodiversity. View Full-Text

We introduce a new model of self-organized criticality (SOC) and show that it is a scaling limit of the sandpile model. Our model is continuous, in contrast to all known models of SOC, and is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is widely used in electronics, photonics, and optics. However, diamond is brittle and can be easily damaged by external forces. Here, we show that diamond can be completely metallized, solely under mechanical strain without phonon instability, and that its electronic bandgap can be completely closed. We also show that diamond can be demetallized, and its bandgap can be opened, by applying tensile strain. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. Our findings are expected to be useful for the development of diamond-based devices and applications. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

This work is a contribution to the development of a new class of plant fungicides. The antifungal activity of the peptide is due to its ability to bind to and disrupt the integrity of the fungal cell wall and membrane. The peptide also binds to bioactive phosphoinositides in the cell, which may be involved in the regulation of fungal cell wall biosynthesis.

The female reproductive tract (FRT) is a complex environment that interacts with the sperm to ensure fertilization. However, the extent to which the FRT contributes to the process of fertilization is largely unknown. Here, we show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the FRT. We also show that the FRT contributes to the sperm proteome, and that the extent of this contribution is dependent on the duration of storage. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the sperm proteome and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. The common human bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease, is caused by mutations in the ultralong protein von Willebrand factor (VWF). We show that the A1 domain in VWF binds to the platelet receptor glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) and that the binding is regulated by flow and by mutations in the A1 domain. The regulation is due to a switch in the conformation of the A1 domain, which increases the rate of binding to platelets. The switch is reversible, and the binding is slowed by mutations. The switch is a mechanism for regulating the binding of VWF to platelets, which is important for the hemostatic system.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is the focus of intense study. The viral component of the microbiome has been difficult to study, in part because of the lack of a comprehensive database. We present a database of human-associated viruses, which is the most comprehensive to date. We use this database to identify previously unknown associations between viruses and disease. We hope that this resource will be useful to the research community.

The temperature of the early Earth has been a topic of intense debate. Here we present a method for determining the temperature of the surface of the early Earth based on the thermostability of enzymes reconstructed from ancient bacteria and archaea. Our results suggest that the temperature of the surface of the early Earth decreased over time, a finding consistent with previous interpretations based on isotopic evidence. This work highlights the importance of integrating different lines of evidence to better understand the history of our planet. (Show more)

Ion channels are the main regulators of ion flow and are important for the normal function of the heart. In this study, we found that the large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel has a unique state-dependent C-inactivation, which is different from that of other K+ channels. This study provides a new perspective for the study of ion channel regulation and may have implications for the development of cardiac drugs.

Malaria parasite invasion of the red blood cell (RBC) is a critical step in the disease pathogenesis. Here, we show that the malaria parasite binds to the surface of the RBC, and this binding alters the physical properties of the RBC, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This finding suggests that invasion is a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is widely used in electronics, photonics, and optics. However, diamond is brittle and easily breaks into pieces. This work shows that diamond can be metallized, and the metallization can be reversed by removing the strain. This work provides a new way to control the properties of diamond. It also provides a new way to control the properties of other materials with a wide bandgap. This work is expected to have a significant impact on the development of new materials and applications.

This study provides evidence that low humidity impairs host defense against influenza infection and exacerbates disease outcome. Our findings suggest that humidity may be a potential target for influenza vaccine and antiviral drug development.

The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree, with words at the leaves and phrases at the branches. However, the neurophysiological evidence for this structure is weak. Here, we show that the brain’s activity during the processing of sentences and word lists is consistent with a model in which the brain first merges words into phrases and then combines phrases into a tree structure. Our results suggest that the brain’s processing of language is based on a merge operation that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. This suggests that the brain may be able to process a sentence in a single pass. Our findings provide initial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists. They also suggest that the brain may be able to process language in a single pass.

Axin is a key component of the Wnt signaling pathway, which is involved in a wide range of biological processes, including development and cancer. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin in vertebrates are regulated differently at the transcriptional and proteostatic level, which confers differential responsiveness to the two forms of Axin. This differential regulation may be used in tissue-specific regulation, which is a common feature in the regulation of redundant genes in vertebrates.

This work provides a detailed description of the brain circuit that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity. We show that the lateral hypothalamus, a brain region that is involved in the regulation of feeding, is capable of inducing eating in sated animals. We also show that this circuit is dependent on dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area and the locus coeruleus. This work provides a basis for further studies of the role of dopamine in the regulation of feeding and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of obesity. (Show more)

The ability to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis between plants and bacteria is a key component of sustainable agriculture. Here, we demonstrate the development of a system that allows the control of the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in barley. This system is based on the ability of plants to produce a signaling molecule that can be used to control the gene expression of the bacteria. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also provides a proof of concept for the use of rhizopine as a signaling molecule in the control of the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis. This work is a significant step toward the development of a synthetic nitrogen cycle in agriculture. (Show more)

We study the effects of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that combined remote-sensed deforestation alerts with training and incentives for community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management. Our results also suggest that the program’s monitors were perceived as new authorities with influence over forest management and that the monitors’ patrols were perceived as substitutes for traditional, unincentivized citizen patrols that suffer from free riding and inhibit timely detection of and responses to deforestation. Our results have implications for the design of forest monitoring and governance systems in the Amazon and beyond. (Less...)

We show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear the sounds of its prey and predators, and even the sounds of its own kind, by outsourcing its hearing to its web. The spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna, which is more sensitive to acoustic waves than the spider’s body. The spider can detect the direction and location of the source of the acoustic wave, and can even localize the source in three dimensions. The spider can also adjust the size of the web to meet its needs. This study provides a unique model for studying the outsourcing and supersizing of sensing and the regulation of the size of the sensing surface. It also provides a new idea for the design of acoustic flow detectors. (Show more)

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a global response to a pandemic pathogen. The development of vaccines for SARS-CoV-2 is a global effort, and the need for a global response is even more apparent in low- and middle-income countries. We report the development of a recombinant protein vaccine candidate that can be manufactured at a large scale, with the potential to produce billions of doses annually. This vaccine candidate can be used to develop a vaccine for COVID-19 in LMICs, and the engineered sequence variant of the RBD can be used to improve the manufacturability and immunogenicity of other vaccine candidates. This work provides a potential solution to the global access challenge of COVID-19 vaccines. (Show more)

We show that the zebrafish homolog of ALK, DrLtk, and the zebrafish homolog of ALKALs, DrALKals, are involved in the development of iridophores, pigment cells of the skin and the larval zebrafish eye. Our results provide evidence for the involvement of ALK/ALKAL signaling in the development of neural crest-derived tissues.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and its emergence is a key event in the history of humankind. However, the early history of plague is poorly understood, and the timing and geographic spread of its emergence is still debated. We present a large dataset of ancient Yersinia pestis genomes from across Eurasia and show that the emergence of plague was a gradual process, with a single lineage persisting for millennia without significant diversification. We also show that the emergence of the flea-adapted form of plague occurred much earlier than previously thought, and that it spread widely across Eurasia. These results provide insights into the early history of plague and its adaptation to its vector. (Less)

This work examined the role of the endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 American presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted support for Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies. They have implications for understanding the role of masculinity in politics and the social construction of gender, race, and class in contemporary society.

The fate of soil organic carbon (SOC) in agricultural systems is of global concern, as it is a key indicator of soil health and a major contributor to climate change. We show that soil management practices that reduce soil disturbance, diversify crop rotations, and integrate livestock can increase SOC storage in the top 15 cm of soil. These results are consistent with a meta-analysis of 1,100 studies from 11 countries worldwide, which shows that these practices can increase SOC storage by 18 to 29% over 29 y. These findings highlight the potential of grasslands to sequester carbon and provide a solution to the global carbon crisis. This study also highlights the importance of long-term field experiments in understanding the effects of agricultural management on soil health and the environment. (Less)

The death toll and economic loss resulting from the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) pandemic are stark reminders that we are vulnerable to zoonotic viral threats. We developed a risk assessment framework to identify wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spillover and spread in humans. We validated the framework using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The resulting ranking of 887 wildlife viruses was used to identify the top 12 with the highest spillover potential. The SpillOver platform is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. We hope that SpillOver will be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health.

Nectar is the main reward that plants offer to pollinators for visitation. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts pollinators, but the mechanisms that underlie its evolution are poorly understood. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of the blood-red flower Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify nesocodin in the red nectar of the hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. Our findings suggest that the red pigment is selectively favored and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work provides insight into the evolution of a key trait that is likely to be important for the success of many plant–pollinator interactions. (Less)

We present a case study of the genetic landscape of the Early Medieval period in Europe. We show that the genetic ancestry of men is mostly consistent with modern northern and central Europeans, but that the genetic ancestry of women is highly heterogeneous, including signals of genetic ancestry from western Europe to East Asia. We also show that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. This study provides insights into the genetic processes that shaped the modern European genetic landscape and the role of women in the shaping of the genetic landscape of the continent.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how HKU4 and HKU5 transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. This study also provides insights into the evolution of bat coronaviruses and their potential to cause human diseases. (Show more)

The human genome is replicated in a discontinuous manner, with the synthesis of DNA lagging behind the replication fork. This process is known as DNA replication, but it is more accurately described as the synthesis of DNA. The synthesis of DNA is a complex process that requires the action of many proteins. One of the most important proteins involved in the synthesis of DNA is the human DNA polymerase δ (pol δ). In this paper, we describe a unique set of assays that allow us to measure the processivity and stability of pol δ. We find that pol δ is a highly processive enzyme that is able to synthesize DNA at a rate of 100 nucleotides per second. However, the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is extremely low, and the enzyme dissociates from the PCNA sliding clamp within 100 ms. These results have profound implications for the synthesis of DNA and the role of pol δ in human disease.

The origin of life is one of the most important problems in biology. In the RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules. In the absence of proteins, can RNA be used to replicate itself and to synthesize other RNA molecules and even proteins? We report the results of an in vitro evolution experiment that led to the development of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can synthesize a variety of RNA molecules, including aptamers, ribozymes, and, in low yield, even tRNA. Furthermore, the polymerase can replicate nucleic acids, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of the PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA. This work provides a foundation for the study of the origins of life and the evolution of RNA-based life.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to study the physical dynamics of five US cities. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our work is a step toward a more complete understanding of the physical processes that shape the urban landscape. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is still unclear. In this study, we found that the treatment of tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathways, can reduce the mortality of severe and critical COVID-19 patients. This study provides a new idea for the treatment of COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but at high concentrations it is toxic. The ability of fungi to sense and respond to copper is well established, but the role of the xanthocillin-derived isocyanide metabolites in copper homeostasis and interactions with competing microbes is unknown. We demonstrate that the xanthocillin BGC is present in a variety of filamentous fungi, and that these metabolites bind copper and impact cellular copper content. The existence of the xanthocillin BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This work provides insight into the role of fungi in the biogeochemical cycling of metals and the impact of fungi on human health. (Show more)

The formation of tridymite, a low-pressure, high-temperature polymorph, in a sedimentary environment is unusual. The detection of tridymite in a sedimentary rock in Gale crater, Mars, is the first evidence of this mineral on another planet. The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary environment on another planet is consistent with the hypothesis that the Martian surface was once covered by a shallow body of water.

Frost is a major environmental stressor of plants and animals in the temperate and boreal zones. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is changing, and that the resistance strategies of trees are adapted to the local frost risk. Our findings have implications for land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are central to the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease, but the mechanisms by which they contribute to disease are not well understood. We show that the development of Th17 cells is contingent on the expression of both Stat4 and T-bet, but not the IL-12 or IFN-γ receptors. Moreover, we show that Th17 cells can provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. Our findings have implications for the development of therapies for inflammatory bowel disease. (Show more)

We report a method to rapidly produce astrocytes from living ALS patients. These cells can be used for disease modeling, high-throughput drug screening, and mechanistic studies. We show that astrocytes derived from ALS patients are toxic to motor neurons, and this toxicity is shared between patients with different genetic causes of ALS. This method will enable the study of disease mechanisms and the development of therapies for ALS. This will help to accelerate the development of treatments for this devastating disease. (Show more)

This study provides a unique example of a pathogen using a host protein to alter the gut microbiota of its vector, the tick. This study also provides a model for understanding the role of the microbiota in pathogen colonization and transmission.

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds. However, the diversity of early pygostylians is limited, and the origin of the modern avian tail is poorly understood. Here, we describe a basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis, and show that it had a mosaic tail structure, combining plesiomorphic nonavian theropod features with derived avian ones. This study increases the known diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding the evolution of the avian tail. (Less)

We show that the increase in water vapor in the stratosphere with increasing tropospheric temperature is a positive feedback that enhances the climate sensitivity of the Earth. This feedback is not included in most climate models, and its inclusion increases the model climate sensitivity by 30%.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, and many of them are green. The color of a vertebrate can be modified by pigments, but the color of its bones and other tissues can be modified by the presence of high concentrations of biliverdin, a pigment that is normally found in the blood. We show that the presence of high concentrations of biliverdin in vertebrates has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and that the mechanism is the same—the presence of a class of proteins that bind biliverdin. We also describe a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. Our results present molecular and functional evidence of recurrent evolution of chlorosis, describe a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily. This work provides a better understanding of the biochemical basis, biology, and evolution of chlorosis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Hypoxia is a feature of many cancers, and is associated with the maintenance of cancer stem cells, which are responsible for tumor initiation and relapse. We report that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase, which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a gene encoding a pluripotency factor. We show that ALKBH5 expression is induced by hypoxia in a HIF-dependent manner, and that ALKBH5 overexpression increases the percentage of breast cancer cells that are cancer stem cell-like. Thus, ALKBH5 expression in hypoxic tumors may be a mechanism by which cancer stem cells are maintained, and may be a therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The use of fetal animal skins for parchment has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we present a simple and objective method for the identification of the animal origin of parchment. We show that the use of fetal animal skins for parchment is not supported by the data.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. We present a precise age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dates from volcanic ash beds. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. Onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle immediately precedes the initiation of extinction and is punctuated by a sharp (3‰), short-lived negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. Carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. Decamillenial to millennial level resolution of the mass extinction and its aftermath will permit a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion. This will establish an accurate time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. (Less)

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a chronic inflammatory disease of the gastrointestinal tract, which is characterized by the presence of inflammation and immune responses in the intestinal mucosa. IBD is a complex disease, and the exact pathogenesis is still unclear. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) plays an important role in the regulation of intestinal inflammation. We generated intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific RORα-deficient mice and found that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. Our study provides a new perspective for the treatment of IBD. (Show more)

We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein in complex with the receptor ACE2 at 8.3 Å resolution. We find that the D614G mutation has led to a more open conformation of the spike, which may facilitate binding to the receptor. This is consistent with the observation that the D614G mutation is the most prevalent in currently circulating SARS-CoV-2 viruses. Our results suggest that the D614G mutation may have a role in increasing the infectivity of the virus. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.
