COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic has resulted in a decline in life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y, which would increase the Black−White life expectancy gap to over 5 y. These projections imply that the pandemic has exacerbated the racial disparities in mortality that have been present for decades.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry and are fundamental to understanding the properties of matter. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, which are the basis of chemistry, change with pressure. We show that the chemical properties of atoms can be used to predict the behavior of matter under pressure. This work is a fundamental contribution to the understanding of the behavior of matter under pressure.

We show that the effects of human ignitions and fire suppression on fire regimes are as important as climate change in driving future warming. This is important for understanding the role of fire in climate change and for assessing the effectiveness of climate mitigation policies. Our results suggest that, in some regions, climate mitigation policies could be complemented by policies to reduce fire activity.

This study provides a new perspective on the role of glycans in the regulation of host–microbe interactions. We show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, by the host to its symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, is a key factor in the maintenance of a healthy symbiosis. This glycan is consumed by the symbiont, which uses it to enhance the oxygenation of the crypts where it resides. This work also highlights the importance of the timing of the provision of nutrients, which can be critical for the stability of the symbiosis. This study provides a new perspective on the role of glycans in the regulation of host–microbe interactions. (Show more)

We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data. We show that the structure of a corpus can be represented as a sequence of topics, and that this representation can be used to identify topics that are not captured by existing variables. Our method can be applied to a wide range of domains, and can be used to identify the gender bias of topics. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. We believe that this approach will be useful to many researchers in the social sciences and beyond.

The second plague pandemic, which started with the arrival of Yersinia pestis in Europe in the mid-14th century, lasted for four centuries. This period is generally understood as the consequence of a single introduction of the plague bacterium into Europe, after which it spread over the continent. Our study shows that this assumption is not supported by the available evidence. We find that the plague bacterium was repeatedly introduced into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our results suggest that the plague bacterium was not permanently established in Europe, but that it was continuously reintroduced from Asia. This finding has important implications for the understanding of the epidemiology of the plague and its impact on medieval society. (Less)

This study provides evidence that a densovirus is responsible for the mass mortality of sea stars on the Pacific Coast of North America. This is the first report of a densovirus associated with a disease outbreak in sea stars. The study also provides evidence that the virus has been present in the region for at least 72 y. This finding has implications for the management of this disease and the species that are affected.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor survival rate. We show that monoclonal antibodies targeting the IL1RAP (IL1R3) receptor can efficiently treat AML in mice. We also show that the antibodies can mediate antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and block IL-1 signaling as modes of action. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Furthermore, the results suggest that the IL1RAP antibody can be used as a tool for the study of the role of IL1RAP in AML. Thus, the results provide a proof of principle for the use of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. (Show more)

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. We also found that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a sex-biased way, with a higher contribution of males from Southeast Asia and Europe. Finally, we found that the genetic structure of the population is influenced by the geography of the island, suggesting that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a dynamic way. These results help to understand the history of Madagascar and the settlement of the Indian Ocean. View Full-Text

Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. We show that the RNA and protein interact and that the protein interferes with the function of the RNA. We also show that the RNA and protein compete for the same binding sites on the target genes. This work provides insight into the regulation of carbon utilization in bacteria. It also demonstrates the importance of considering the protein component of sRNAs in understanding their function. This work is important for understanding the regulation of carbon utilization in bacteria and the evolution of small RNAs. It also provides a model for the evolution of dual-function RNAs.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of new therapeutics and vaccines against SARS-CoV-2 variants. (Show more)

Crop experts are the first line of defense for the US agricultural sector, and their assessments are critical for the management of crop production. However, the information they provide is often not used in decision-making processes. We show that the information provided by crop experts can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. Our results demonstrate the potential of using crop expert assessments to improve the accuracy of agricultural forecasts and highlight the importance of leveraging the knowledge of the local farming community. Our findings have implications for the development of large-scale continuous crop monitoring systems, which are key to detect and manage agricultural production anomalies.

Language is a complex system that requires the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism that supports memory for linguistic information in the brain. We show that the firing rate of neurons can be reduced through synaptic and intrinsic plasticity, and that this can support memory for short periods of time. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and that it can support the binding of linguistic features over time. This work provides a computational neurobiology of language that can be tested in future experiments.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change remains uncertain. We present the results of a global synthesis of soil respiration measurements, spanning nine biomes and 27 temperature manipulation studies. Our analysis reveals that soil respiration does not increase in response to experimental warming in most biomes, and that the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration decreases with increasing temperature. These results suggest that soil respiration may be less responsive to climate change in colder regions, which may have important implications for the global carbon cycle.

The evolution of the plastid genome is a key element in understanding the origin and evolution of life. Here, we show that the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle leads to a relaxation of selection pressure on the plastid genome. We demonstrate that the evolutionary rates of the plastid genome are modulated by the macrostructural and microstructural changes in the genome, and by the establishment of the parasitic lifestyle. Our findings have implications for the evolution of the plastid genome and for the origin of life. View Full-Text

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the risks of climate change in South Africa and globally. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This work highlights the need for urgent mitigation efforts to reduce the risk of future droughts in SSA. (Show more)

The discovery of a new quasicrystal in the red trinitite, the first nuclear test explosion, is of great scientific interest. However, the discovery of a new quasicrystal is also of great historical interest, as it is the oldest known anthropogenic quasicrystal. The discovery of this material, and its precise dating, is of great interest to the fields of science, technology, and history.

(Bacterio)chlorophylls are the light harvesting pigments of oxygenic photosynthetic bacteria and are essential for the capture of solar energy. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in photosynthesis, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes, which use different chemistries. Here we show that the two enzymes are part of a larger family, and that the enzymes have evolved to use different subunits.

Neuroinflammation is a major feature of many neurodegenerative diseases, and neuroinflammation is also a major feature of multiple sclerosis (MS), the most common chronic inflammatory disease of the central nervous system. In this study, we found that neuroinflammation was reduced in both the early and later stages of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE) in microglia/macrophage-specific ASK1 knockout mice, whereas only the later-stage neuroinflammation was ameliorated in astrocyte-specific ASK1 knockout mice. We also found that ASK1 signaling in microglia played a major role in generating and maintaining disease. Activated astrocytes produce key inflammatory mediators, including CCL2, that further activated and recruited microglia/macrophages, in an astrocytic ASK1-dependent manner. Our findings demonstrate cell-type–specific roles of ASK1 and suggest phase-specific ASK1-dependent glial cell interactions in EAE pathophysiology. We propose glial ASK1 as a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. (PsycINFO Database Record

Autism is a complex disorder with a variety of symptoms, and the etiology is not yet fully understood. We used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. Our results suggest that behavioral inflexibility is a common feature of autism and that the underlying mechanism is related to the activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting. These findings may facilitate the identification of the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms. (Show more)

This work is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date. It shows that, on average, people around the world react more strongly to negative than positive news content. It also highlights individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content, and suggests that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of store-operated Ca2+ entry, which is involved in a wide range of physiological and pathological processes. Mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein STIM1 result in severe immune dysfunction and myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1, which are associated with a Stormorken syndrome of bleeding diathesis, thrombocytopenia, miosis, and tubular myopathy. We also identify a Stormorken-like syndrome of bleeding diathesis and miosis in ORAI1 mutants. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. (Show more)

We have developed a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease that allows us to study the spreading of aggregates in a defined subset of neurons. We show that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain, causing non–cell-autonomous pathology. We also show that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1, indicating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide a model for studying the mechanisms of spreading and the propagation of disease in neurodegenerative diseases. They also provide a platform for studying the effects of therapeutic interventions on the spreading of aggregates and the progression of disease. (Show more)

Bats are the only mammals that can survive in caves, and they are increasingly accepted as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified and characterized a protein that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus, and found that this protein is a potent immunomodulator that inhibits the antiviral immune response of the host and facilitates viral infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting this immunomodulator. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of bats in the emergence of zoonotic viruses and may lead to the development of new antiviral drugs. (Show more)

Cancer is a disease of cell growth, and one-carbon metabolism is essential for cell growth. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the one-carbon metabolism enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), and used it to identify a cancer cell-line screen. We show that SHMT inhibition is particularly effective in B-cell lines, and that this effect is rooted in defective glycine import. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. This work provides a foundation for the development of a new class of cancer therapeutics. (Show more)

We show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord of patients with ALS are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, the inclusions contain a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This metastable state is likely the result of a combination of factors, including the presence of toxic species, the presence of stress proteins, and the presence of a variety of other proteins that are not part of the native interaction network. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The study of the early diversification of the flowering plants is, therefore, of great importance. Montsechia is a plant that was first described more than 100 y ago. It has been poorly understood and misinterpreted in the past. Based on a detailed study of more than 1,000 specimens, Montsechia is shown to be an aquatic plant, similar to Ceratophyllum, and to be the sister to Ceratophyllum in a cladistic analysis. This study opens the possibility that aquatic habitats played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages.

The evolution of viruses is of great interest to the fields of virology and epidemiology. In this study, we present the first ancient viral sequences from human remains, which are dated to 60 thousand years ago. We find that the evolution of human parvovirus B19 (B19V) is slower than previously thought, and we are able to date the recombination event that formed the current B19V genotype 2. These results emphasize the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. This study also highlights the potential of ancient viral sequences for the study of ancient epidemics. (Show more)

We show that the rate of acceleration of global mean sea level over the last 25 y is consistent with the rate of acceleration of many other geophysical systems, such as the rate of increase of ocean heat content. We also show that the rate of acceleration of global mean sea level is consistent with the rate of acceleration of the rate of increase of ocean heat content.

Pain is a normal part of life, but it is not normal that pain is increasing with age in America today. We show that pain has increased with age in America for all adults, but that the increase has been faster for those born after 1950 than for those born before 1950. This pattern is not explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity. Instead, it fits a more general pattern seen in the ongoing erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950. If this trend continues, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults; tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. In this work, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed picture of the structure and dynamics of a key enzyme intermediate. This work highlights the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a mechanistic view of enzyme reactions, and the importance of the chemical environment in enzyme catalysis.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe pneumonia caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific treatment for MERS, and the high case fatality rate highlights the need for the development of effective antiviral therapies. Here, we show that remdesivir, a nucleotide analog that inhibits viral RNA synthesis, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial of MERS-CoV infection, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This would be of benefit in the current pandemic.

This study provides a new perspective on the role of glycans in the regulation of host–microbe interactions. We show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, by the host to its symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, is critical for the maintenance of a stable symbiosis. This glycan is consumed only at night, when the host and symbiont are in close proximity, and the catabolism of chitin is required for the periodic acidification of the crypts, which enhances the luminescence of the symbiont. This study suggests that the provision of glycans may be a general mechanism for the regulation of the activities of symbionts associated with epithelial surfaces. This idea is supported by the observation that other hosts may similarly regulate the activities of symbionts through the strategic provision of glycans. (Show more)

This work is about the importance of relationships in schools, and the power of teachers to shape them. It is also about the importance of suspending students, and the power of suspending to shape relationships.

DNA alkylation is one of the most common DNA lesions, which can lead to a variety of diseases. However, the molecular mechanism of how DNA alkylation affects transcription is still unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated the effects of alkylated thymidine lesions on transcription. We found that the transcription reaction is stalled at the alkylated thymidine lesion, and the stalling is exacerbated by the proofreading activity of RNA polymerase II. We also found that the lesion can be bypassed in two different ways, depending on the location of the alkyl group in the DNA base. This work provides important mechanistic insights into the effects of alkylated DNA lesions on transcription. This knowledge will be useful for the development of new strategies for the treatment of diseases caused by DNA alkylation. (Show more)

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. To better understand the mechanisms of infection, we engineered MERS-CoV to resist proteolysis during the sequential cleavages required for virus entry. We found that these mutations compromised infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into other cell types. These findings suggest that the first cleavages are important determinants of MERS-CoV tropism, and may be significant determinants of virulence.

This study provides evidence that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria can increase the proportion of vegetarian meals purchased by 40% or more. This is a significant contribution to the literature on the environmental and health benefits of plant-based diets, and it has important implications for the food service industry and the food industry more generally. The results suggest that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in catering settings could have a significant impact on the health and well-being of populations, as well as on the environment. This study also provides evidence that nudging meal selection can be effective in the real world, and it provides a model for future research on the effectiveness of nudging in the food domain. Cancer is a disease of the cell surface, and the surfaceome is the interface for the cell to interact with the extracellular space. We have developed a method to study the surfaceome of cancer cells, and applied it to study the surfaceome of cancer cells expressing oncogenes. We find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is expected to be useful for drug discovery and biomarker discovery. (Show more)

In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. What are the effects of vote-by-mail? In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of universal vote-by-mail—a policy under which every voter is mailed a ballot in advance of the election—on electoral outcomes. We find that universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates, in line with previous estimates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our findings suggest that vote-by-mail is a safe and effective way to conduct elections during the pandemic. We hope that our findings will help to inform the public debate about the future of elections in the United States. (Less…)

SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, has been shown to be highly infectious and to cause severe disease. In this work, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein. We show that the structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 is similar to that of SARS-CoV, but with the addition of two unique interfaces. These interfaces may be important for the unique properties of SARS-CoV-2, including immune evasion and the ability to form large-scale assemblies. This work provides insight into the molecular basis of the severity of the COVID-19 disease. (Show more)

Cerebral edema is a life-threatening condition, and the mechanisms underlying its development are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats, and that this is mediated, at least in part, by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on the cerebral cortex via its receptor CRFR1, leading to activation of astrocytes and water influx into the brain, and cerebral edema. These findings may help to develop new therapies for cerebral edema. (Show more)

We live in an age of big data and complex statistical modeling. The challenge for the data scientist is to find the right balance between the need to find the strongest associations and the need to avoid overfitting to the data. We describe some recent developments in selective inference that allow us to set a higher bar for declaring significant associations. We illustrate the use of these methods in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. We hope that this will help the data scientist to avoid some of the pitfalls of complex statistical modeling.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step for the development of vascular networks. However, the generation of ECs from nonvascular cells is still a challenge. Here, we report the generation of endothelial cells from nonvascular cells by using a single transcription factor, ets variant 2 (ETV2). This study provides a new approach for the generation of ECs and the development of vascular networks. This approach can be applied to the generation of ECs for the treatment of vascular disorders and the development of vascular networks for the regeneration of organs. This study also provides a new approach for the generation of ECs and the development of vascular networks. This approach can be applied to the treatment of vascular disorders and the development of vascular networks. (Show more)

We report the discovery of a third class of ligands for the RTKs anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk). We show that these ligands are essential for the development of iridophores, a specialized epidermal tissue that is responsible for the coloration of the zebrafish. This discovery has implications for our understanding of the role of RTKs in development and for the development of new therapies for cancer and pigmentation disorders.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a major public health problem. Although the molecular mechanisms of T2D are well established, the molecular basis of insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction is still unknown. Herein, we found that the interferon-induced STING plays a critical role in the regulation of insulin sensitivity and β-cell function. We also found that STING deficiency in β-cells causes impaired glucose-stimulated insulin secretion, which is associated with the loss of Pax6 in β-cells. These findings provide a new perspective for the treatment of T2D. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are responsible for annual seasonal epidemics and occasional severe pandemics. The packaging of the viral genome is a key step in the assembly of the virion, and the packaging signals are known to be involved in this process. However, the packaging of the viral genome is not fully understood. Here, we identified a direct interaction between two viral RNA segments of an avian influenza virus. We show that this interaction is required for the packaging of the viral genome and that it is involved in the selective packaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. This interaction is not widely conserved among influenza A viruses, suggesting that it might play a role in genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. This work provides a better understanding of the packaging mechanism of the influenza A virus. (Show more)

The development of atherosclerosis is a complex process involving a series of events, including the activation of proatherosclerotic phenotypes in vascular endothelial cells. In this study, we found that the activation of YAP/TAZ by disturbed flow is a critical event in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. Our results suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising strategy for the prevention and treatment of atherosclerosis. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the functional role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesions and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the prevention and treatment of atherosclerosis. (Show more)

Wildfires are a natural part of many ecosystems, but they can also be a threat to human life and property. In the United States, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. We show that humans have vastly expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire in the United States, and that this expansion has been driven by human activities. Our results highlight the need for increased management of human-started wildfires, which are a substantial driver of overall fire risk to ecosystems and economies.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to study the physical dynamics of five US cities over the course of 10 y. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, these results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods may be a useful indicator of the economic and demographic characteristics of the people who live there. This work is a step toward a more complete understanding of the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are a sustainable alternative to chemical pesticides, but their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we report the identification of a scorpion TRP channel as a receptor of plant-derived natural repellents, which mediates avoidance behavior. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods, and may help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It should also help the understanding of the evolution of the arthropod–plant interaction. This work is expected to contribute to the conservation of biodiversity and the sustainable development of agriculture. (Show more)

We present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of plasma ZIKV burden in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We show that the time between cell infection and viral production is likely short, the rate of viral production is rapid, and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is likely long. We also show that antiviral treatment can reduce the time to undetectable plasma viral load, but that the timing of treatment is critical. We predict that favipiravir, a polymerase inhibitor with activity against ZIKV, can reduce the peak median viral load by ∼3 logs and shorten the time to undetectable median viral load by ∼2 d, whereas treatment given 2 d postinfection is mostly ineffective in accelerating plasma viral load loss. These results can be used to guide the development of treatment strategies for the prevention and control of ZIKV infection. (Show more)

Coral reefs are among the most valuable ecosystems on Earth, but they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors. In this study, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. Our results provide insights into the processes that lead to the loss of the coral–algal symbiosis and may help to explain the stability of the coral holobiont in light of its metabolic interactions. This understanding may ultimately help to predict the fate of coral reefs in a changing climate.

The intestinal epithelium is a complex barrier that protects the host from the environment and regulates nutrient absorption and immune responses. In this study, we show that the loss of BMP signaling in the epithelium leads to the development of intestinal tumors, which in turn activate a JNK-dependent feedback loop that triggers a dysbiotic microbiome and tumor growth. Our findings identify a mechanism by which the activity of the epithelium controls the activity of the microbiome, and highlight the importance of controlling the activity of JNK signaling to maintain intestinal barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. These results have implications for understanding the role of the microbiome in the development of intestinal tumors and for developing strategies to control tumorigenesis. (Show more)

Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is heterogeneous, and many patients relapse. We show that chemotherapy can increase the expression of the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1, which is associated with the expression of genes involved in the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, and BMI1. We also show that ROR1 expression is associated with the development of breast cancer stemness, which is a feature of cancer cells that may contribute to the development of metastasis. Finally, we show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts with a humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab can reduce the ability of the tumors to metastasize and reestablish engraftment in Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy in patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The timing of the start of deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere is one of the most debated issues in the last-glacial cycle. We show that the start of deglaciation is linked to a volcanic eruption series, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a reduction in cloud cover. This, in turn, caused a warming of the lower stratosphere, which led to a poleward shift of the Southern Hemisphere westerlies and a rapid advance of the Antarctic ice sheet.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, they are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts. We present a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of the world’s catch comes from river basins with high levels of human and economic stress. Our analysis also shows that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, particularly in regions where alternative sources of nutrition and employment are scarce. Our results highlight the importance of rivers and lakes in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein, but also the need for improved management of these critical ecosystems.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable character of the negative electrode material is the key to achieve high-energy aqueous batteries. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters. This work provides a new strategy for the development of inherently safe energy devices. This work is expected to promote the development of aqueous batteries. The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the nervous system. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, neurons are largely incapable of regenerating after injury. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS. This discovery has implications for understanding the molecular mechanisms that control the regenerative capacity of the adult nervous system.

We present a detailed map of recombination in a flowering plant, which is the closest relative of humans. Our results suggest that the pattern of recombination in plants is similar to that in animals, and that the ancient mechanism of recombination initiation in eukaryotes is conserved.

The resting state network (RSN) hypothesis has been proposed to explain the functional organization of the human brain. However, the RSN concept has been defined using a small fraction of the total neuronal activity. Here, we show that the dominant RSN in healthy subjects is topographically similar to the default mode network, whereas in Parkinson’s disease (PD) it is subordinated to a disease-related pattern. In addition, we show that the dominant RSN is deactivated during task performance, and that this abnormality is partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. Finally, we show that the dominant RSN is reduced in Alzheimer’s disease, and that this abnormality is already present at diagnosis. These results provide a direct link between the functional organization of the brain and its metabolic activity, and they have implications for the development of new imaging techniques for the study of brain function.

We describe a 5′ cap structure in yeast that is modified by nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+). This cap structure is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs, and is not found on the same transcripts in bacteria. We also show that the 5′ cap structure is not required for transcription, but is required for translation. This work provides insight into the function of the 5′ cap structure in yeast and may have implications for the function of the 5′ cap in other organisms.

We report that epigenetic DNA-methylation differences at specific loci persist for several years during the long-term follow-up of people with diabetes, and that these differences are associated with glycemia. These results support an epigenetic explanation for the metabolic memory phenomenon, the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) on the progression of microvascular complications in the long-term follow-up Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study. These findings may also have implications for the development of epigenetic therapies for diabetes and other metabolic diseases.
This study provides a comprehensive understanding of the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of TNBC. Our findings may aid in the design of therapies for TNBC. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease that affects the quality of life of millions of people worldwide. The present study shows that the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol-dependent subjects, and that some of them develop gut leakiness, which is associated with psychological symptoms of the disease. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of gut barrier dysfunction and in the behavioral disorders of alcohol dependence. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study may also contribute to the development of new therapeutic strategies for this disease. (PsycINFO Database Record

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals, which are responsible for the characteristic aroma. In this study, we identified a gene essential for the production of a large number of these volatiles. We show that this gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylation of a nitrogen-containing precursor. This work provides a major advance in our understanding of the biosynthesis of tomato flavor, and will be of interest to researchers in the field of plant metabolism. (Show more)

We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. This is important because the effects of climate change are expected to be most pronounced at the extremes of the temperature range. Our results have important implications for the conservation of biodiversity and the functioning of ecosystems, and suggest that the effects of climate change on biodiversity and ecosystem functioning will be more severe than previously thought.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation, but the organization of its neurons is poorly understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in the MEC of freely behaving mice. We found that grid cells, which are thought to be responsible for the formation of a mental map of the environment, are organized in a distinct manner from other neurons. These data provide a detailed view of the organization of neurons in MEC and their relationships with other brain regions, which will be useful for understanding the function of MEC and its role in navigation. Flowering is a complex process, which is regulated by a variety of environmental and developmental cues. In this study, we show that flowering of the host plant is required for flowering of the parasite, and that this flowering synchronization is mediated by the FT protein. This study demonstrates that flowering is a common signal for both host and parasite, and that flowering synchronization is a common strategy for parasite survival.

Parkinson’s disease is the most common movement disorder, and dopamine-related dysfunction is thought to be central to its pathogenesis. However, the mechanisms by which dopamine neurons fail in the disease are not fully understood. Here, we describe a previously unrecognized system within the dopamine-containing system of the brain, the striosome–dendron bouquet, which is likely to be critical to the function of this system.

We all know it when we feel it, but how do we know when two people are feeling connected to each other? We show that the speed with which people respond to each other is a robust predictor of how connected they feel. This signal is used by people to assess the quality of their connections with others, and by third-party listeners to assess the quality of the connections between two people.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart and is responsible for the generation of the heartbeat. SAN cells are responsible for the generation of the heartbeat and are the only cells in the heart that are able to initiate an action potential. SAN cells are also the only cells in the heart that have the ability to initiate a spontaneous action potential. This study reveals that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SAN cells that links SR Ca2+ store content with electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane, thereby contributing to automaticity of the SAN. This study provides a better understanding of the role of STIM1 in the heart and may lead to the development of new therapies for heart failure. (Show more)

The beneficial effects of silicon (Si) on plant growth and stress tolerance have been well documented, but the role of Si in mediating plant resistance against insect herbivores has not been explored. Here, we show that the accumulation of Si in rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that the interaction between Si and JA in defense against insect herbivores involves priming of JA-mediated defense responses by Si and the promotion of Si accumulation by JA. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms by which plants use silicon to enhance resistance against insect herbivores. (Show more)

This study provides a new perspective on the role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism and opens up new avenues for the development of new therapies for diseases associated with ether lipid accumulation.

Language is a complex system that requires the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism that supports memory for linguistic information in the brain. We show that the firing rate of neurons can be reduced through synaptic and intrinsic plasticity, and that this can support memory for a range of time scales. We demonstrate that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and that it can support the binding of linguistic features over time. This work provides a computational neurobiology of language that can be tested in future experiments.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in plant biology. Here, we report the delivery of siRNAs to plants with DNA nanostructures and show that the delivery efficiency depends on the geometry of the DNA nanostructures. We also show that the delivery efficiency correlates with the gene silencing efficiency but that the endogenous gene silencing pathway depends on the attachment locus of the siRNA. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is expected to be useful for the delivery of biomolecules to plants in the future. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We show that the majority of the nutrients that fuel algal blooms in the nearshore zone of Lake Michigan come from small tributaries that drain the surrounding landscape. Our findings suggest that the importance of small tributaries in driving coastal eutrophication is greater than previously thought. This work highlights the need for a more comprehensive approach to managing nutrient inputs to large water bodies, which are often dominated by a small number of large tributaries.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is able to absorb work from its surroundings only in rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of the environmental forcing. We show that the dynamics of the network can be described by a simple master equation, and we provide a detailed analysis of the dynamics of the system. Our results suggest that the environment may play a role in the design of catalytic systems, and they may have implications for the design of catalytic processes in the real world.

We show that the effects of NMDA-receptor antibodies on the brain can be explained by changes in the dynamics of the brain’s microcircuits. This work offers a mechanistic explanation for the effects of these antibodies on the brain, and may lead to a better understanding of the mechanisms underlying the effects of other neuropsychiatric drugs. This may also help to explain the wide range of effects that can be seen in patients, and may lead to a better understanding of the mechanisms underlying the effects of other neuropsychiatric drugs.

The history of abrupt climate change is a key area of research in the field of Earth system history. However, the history of carbon perturbation events is poorly understood. Here, we present a detailed study of a carbon perturbation event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that this event was the result of a global warming event that was triggered by the injection of organic matter into the ocean. This event is a key example of the role that organic matter can play in the Earth system and the potential for it to play a role in the climate system today.
We show that the certification of palm oil, the most important commodity in the world, has a positive impact on the conservation of forests and the reduction of fires.

The exocytosis process is essential for the transport of molecules from the endoplasmic reticulum to the plasma membrane and the recycling of the endocytic vesicles to the plasma membrane. The exocyst complex is involved in the final steps of the exocytosis process. In this study, we discovered a small molecule that inhibits the exocytosis process in plants and humans. This study provides a valuable tool for studying the regulation of the exocytosis process and a potential target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

In many vertebrates, the sex of an individual is determined by a single genetic locus. In species with a single sex determination locus, the sex of an individual is determined by the same genetic locus that determines the development of the gonads. In species with multiple sex determination alleles, the sex of an individual can be determined by any of the alleles. Here we show that the multiple alleles of sex determination in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii can produce a modular set of secondary sexual characteristics, including differences in the shape of the head and the shape of the genital opening. These results suggest that the multiple alleles of sex determination can produce a greater range of phenotypes, and that the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles can have a greater impact on the evolution of secondary sexual characteristics than previously thought.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by two distinct forms of reactive oxygen species. One of these, generated by the oxidation of vitamin A aldehyde adducts, is a product of photooxidation and photodegradation of the pigment melanin. The other, generated by Fenton chemistry, is a product of the photooxidation of the pigment rhodopsin. We show that the levels of iron in the retina, which are known to be important for the metabolism of vitamin A, also play a role in the photodegradation of the pigment rhodopsin. These findings have implications for the health of the retina and the photoreceptors that it contains. (Show more)

Predators are the main drivers of biodiversity and ecosystem functioning, and thus are fundamental components of food webs. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, as predators become more specialized, they become less efficient. Here we show that the evolution of specialization in siphonophores, a group of pelagic cnidarians, is not a dead end, but rather a process that has led to the diversification of prey types. Our results suggest that the evolution of specialization in siphonophores has been shaped by the evolution of morphological innovations, and that these innovations have been linked to the diversification of prey types. Our findings contribute to understanding the evolution of specialization in predators, and the role of morphological evolution in the diversification of food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolution. However, the origins of the distinctive features of the human hand are poorly understood because of the paucity of hand fossils in the hominin fossil record between 800,000 and 1.8 My old. Here we show that the third metacarpal styloid process, a key feature of the modern human hand, was present in a fossil from East Africa that dates to 1.42 My. This fossil thus provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key shared derived characteristic of modern human and Neandertal hand morphology and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This finding has implications for the evolution of the human hand and the origins of modern human-like behavior. (Less)

Cancer is a disease of cell growth, and one-carbon metabolism is essential for cell growth. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the one-carbon metabolism enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), and used it to identify a cancer cell-line screen. We show that SHMT inhibition is particularly effective in B-cell lines, and that this effect is rooted in defective glycine import. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. This work provides a foundation for the development of a new class of cancer therapeutics. This study shows that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets, and that this impact can be mitigated by the presence of natural forests. This study has important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals.

The mechanization of agriculture has greatly increased the capacity of farm machinery, allowing for higher output of food. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
